Award.AwardTitle: An Integrative Approach to Elucidate Systemic RNA Trafficking
Award.AbstractNarration: How basic processes in individual cells within a multicellular organism are integrated to enable development, function and response to the environment is a central issue in modern biology. Cell-to-cell trafficking of RNA is a recently discovered mechanism that controls gene regulation, viral infection, cellular antiviral responses, and cell-to-cell communication. This project investigates how an RNA produced in a cell is selected for transport into neighboring cells and even to distant organs in a plant, a basic mechanistic question of fundamental importance to understand trafficking regulation for all RNAs. Potato spindle tuber viroid (PSTVd) infection will be used as a simple experimental model to test the hypothesis that an RNA has distinct structural motifs to interact with cellular factors to potentiate trafficking across successive cellular boundaries from the plant surface to the centrally located vascular tissue for long-distance transport. Specifically, the project will (1) analyze a series of trafficking-defective mutants of PSTVd to identify the RNA motifs mediating trafficking through different cellular boundaries, (2) test the predicted three-dimensional structural model of a trafficking motif through extensive mutational analyses, and (3) determine the role of a plant protein in PSTVd trafficking. Results from the project will provide groundbreaking insights about how an infectious RNA has evolved distinct structural elements to use cellular machinery to establish infection, and help develop a conceptual framework to study the mechanisms of RNA trafficking underlying many biological processes. This project will include training of undergraduate and graduate students. This training will expose students to cutting-edge cross-disciplinary research approaches to study fundamental biological problems. The project will also enhance science education for elementary/middle/high school students and secondary school teachers, including traditionally underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How basic processes in individual cells within a multicellular organism are integrated to enable development, function and response to the environment is a central question in modern biology. Cell-to-cell trafficking of RNA is emerging as a new paradigm for gene regulation at the organismal level in plants, in addition to its fundamental role in the systemic spread of viral infection and defense response. Therefore, to advance our understanding of how a plant develops, functions internally and responds to the environment, we must elucidate how RNA trafficking across various cellular boundaries is regulated.

This project tested the hypothesis that specific structural elements in an RNA mediate trafficking of the RNA across distinct cellular boundaries in a plant, by using Potato spindle tuber viroid (PSTVd) infection of Nicotiana benthamiana as a simple and productive model system. Viroids are single-stranded, circular and noncoding RNAs that infect plants. Without encoding proteins, these RNAs must interact directly with cellular machineries to replicate and spread within a plant. Therefore, PSTVd infection represents a valuable model to uncover fundamental mechanisms of plant function.        

In this project, a series of PSTVd mutants were generated and analyzed for their functions in replication in single cells and systemic infection in a whole plant. The analyses identified many mutants that are capable of replication but incapable of systemic infection. These mutants are essentially defective in trafficking between cells. Cellular localization studies were then undertaken to identify the cellular boundaries some of these mutants failed to traffic through, therefore indicating that the affected PSTVd RNA structural elements play a critical role in mediating trafficking across these cellular boundaries. Further analyses revealed the three- dimensional structures of these RNA elements.

These findings should help studies to identify RNA structures for trafficking in other types of RNAs, and to identify the protein factors that interact with the RNA structures for trafficking. This project trained postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students in developing and utilizing multiple approaches to investigate basic biological problems.
